title: How to avoid burn-in on an LG OLED TV - Quora

response.answer_text: The short answer is you can’t. The nature of OLEDs is that the blue phosphor will age faster than the others. The TV compensates for this phenomenon by keeping track of every pixel’s run time and intensity history, and stores this history of every pixel in protected memory on the control board. As the blue (particularly) phosphor darkens, the TV increases the drive to the pixel using it’s learned map to compensate. The screen seems unburned but it’s actually masked. This is apparent when the OLED control board (where the memory is kept) is replaced. With no mapping of pixel history for the original screen, the burns appear out of nowhere in full glory. Now, the longer answer is that you can mitigate the burn by reducing the contrast/picture control. The TV as delivered drives the pixels way too hard. Pick up a calibration DVD (assuming you still have a player) and follow calibration procedures, particularly for black level and contrast. Or, simply reduce the contrast/picture control by half.. Q:How do I avoid burn-in on an LG OLED TV?

“How do I avoid burn-in on an LG OLED TV?” By simply making sure that you don’t have the same images (or parts of images) on screen for hours on end. I use my OLED primarily for watching movies and TV series (without logos on them) and the risk of burn-in is absolutely minimal as the image constantly changes. Using OLED for computer work or gaming might lead to burn in, which is why I don’t use it for those things. Also, I don’t play video games.
